subject: Re: Junitreport runs out of memory.
msgSnippet: I had a similar problem specifically with JUnitReport, which cannot be started in a forked JVM. The solution to that problem is to start ant itself with more

I had a similar problem specifically with JUnitReport, which cannot be
started in a forked JVM. The solution to that problem is to start ant
itself with more java heap using the ANT_OPTS environment variable.

The important point here is that ANT_OPTS is an operating system
environment variable, just like JAVA_HOME or ANT_HOME, not an ant
property or a command line argument, which was how I was trying to use
it at first. Don't make the same mistake I did!

Try this where ever you define your JAVA_HOME and ANT_HOME, such as
~/.bash_profile:

ANT_OPTS=-Xmx80M # do some tests to figure out the minimume size you
need...
JAVA_HOME=/javahome # or where ever...
ANT_HOME=/anthome # or where ever...
export $ANT_OPTS $JAVA_HOME $ANT_HOME 

-- Joe

debug

> > > Does anyone know of a workaround.
> > 
> > This happens when there is a lot of console output. One hack 
> > is to use 
> > the "noframes" stylesheet, ...
> > 
> > Another workaround would be to redirect debug logging away 
> > from stdout  ...
> > This might also be a Xalan defect. ...
> 
> Great ideas, I will try them
>
